tweet: Would love to see the boomers vs. millennials breakout on this poll.  Boomers: Back in my day the market went down every third year.  Millennials: Since the S&P 500 is a riskless asset, you have to choose that +9%.  Not even close.
good business in a great category = never make money.    One element of that formula must be off.    What if the category value actually just gets extracted by FB, GOOG, PINS, SNAP, etc.?

Personally donâ€™t think Tesla software is what made it successful.  No margin of safety in engineering is what made performance seem so outlandish.  Others (VW) have figured out the propulsion and battery management.  UI may be different ballgame. Apple has advantages.

$RVLV can choose growth or very good profitability. Right now market is saying they can have both. Growth stalled relative to comps b/c management has chosen profitability - gets to blame COVID for now. They have to pay the man ($FB,$GOOG,$SNAP) to grow. Tough pill to swallow.

$FB monetization should start growing faster than costs per user over next 18-24 months -->   EBIT/DAU/Month has been stagnant for 2 years but should start growing again.  Margins up -> probably good for stock.
absolutely and that is part of the bull case, I would argue.  doesn't take much to move the needle.  Meanwhile, consensus says $FB grows sequentially in Q3 3X $PINS total rev in the Q.
Should bode well for online ads ($FB and $PINS) - surprising no one, except maybe in magnitude?

Long $AMZN, but if every day is Day 1, what day is it really when sending dickpics?  Day 3,650?  Founder acting like tomorrow could be the last day, doesn't shoot those off like Brett Favre at a sorority mixer.

$FB and $GOOG are just too big to move the needle that much.  $PINS, not so much.  And, integration to make it easier for $SHOP stores to immediately advertise on $PINS happened in early May.  Doesn't mean a storefront couldn't advertise, just took more work.

Last 3.5 years $TSLA has spent $1.4B per year about in R&D. It has been declining to bolster income & pump stock for S&P inclusion.  $GM planning on spending $4B per year on the platform, but I'm sure they're 10 years behind and will stay there. The cavalry is coming...

I don't have any hard data.  If you look at history of GSI, or Target/Amazon relationship, you can likely draw the conclusion that it is all a negotiation. If there is too much value left on table, they leave.  My bet is they usually just negotiate lower take rates with vendor.
$AMZN breaking out.  Should be the greatest beneficiary of the unfortunate pandemic.
